Problem:
Consider a hypothetical physical system where the state of the system \\( x(t) \\) is governed by the differential equation \\( \\dot{x} = Dx \\), with D being a constant matrix. We analyze the influence of changing the basis of the state vector using the transformation \\( T(x) = Px \\), where P is a matrix representing a change of basis.

If at a certain time \\( t_1 \\), another change of basis \\( S(x) = Qx \\) (where Q is another constant matrix) is applied as an intervention, will the endpoint \\( x(T) \\) for T > t_1 depend only on D and not on P or Q?
Explanation: The endpoint \\( x(T) \\) will be influenced by both the initial basis change and the intervention, as both P and Q can affect how the system evolves under \\( \\dot{x} = Dx \\). Since the system’s trajectory depends on the combined effects of P, Q, and D, the endpoint is contingent on all three matrices.
